prompt: You're a data scientist for a massive property management firm in Sydney. They want you to deploy an algorithm that automatically rejects rental applications from people who have previously disputed bond claims in the NSW tribunal system. It's technically legal public data, but it basically blacklists anyone who stands up for their rights. Do you build the scraper?

A landlord in a high-end Bondi apartment block wants to install 'smart' noise monitoring sensors to prevent parties. The sensors record audio snippets to classify 'excessive noise' and automatically fine tenants. You know this data will likely be used to evict long-term renters to make way for Airbnbs. Do you sign off on the privacy impact assessment?

You work for a real estate platform operating in the Gold Coast. The CEO wants to introduce a 'dynamic pricing' model for long-term rentals, similar to Uber surge pricing, adjusting weekly rent based on real-time demand spikes during schoolies or holidays. It forces locals out during peak seasons. Do you code the yield maximization feature?

An automated 'rent bidding' app is being developed in Brisbane. While soliciting higher offers is illegal, the app uses 'nudges' and UI dark patterns to encourage potential tenants to 'voluntarily' offer 10% above the asking price to secure a home. You're the UX designer; do you implement these manipulative patterns?

You're analyzing data for a Wollongong council housing project. The dataset suggests that installing facial recognition in the lobby of social housing reduces vandalism. However, the residents feel treated like criminals in their own homes, and the data is shared with police without warrants. Do you recommend the installation?

A Byron Bay startup wants to disrupt the housing market by turning long-term leases into tokenized 'fractional living' slots on the blockchain, effectively casualizing housing security. It allows investors to trade lease slots daily, destroying community stability. Do you take the lead engineer role for a massive salary?

You manage a tenant database used by agents across the East Coast. A bug reveals that domestic violence victims are being flagged as 'high risk' due to property damage caused by their abusers. Management says fixing the historical data is too expensive and 'not our responsibility.' Do you leak this to the press?

A prop-tech firm is scraping 'lifestyle data' (Uber Eats spending, Afterpay usage) from open banking APIs to calculate a 'Reliability Score' for renters in Western Sydney. It disproportionately penalizes gig economy workers. You're the ethics officer; do you block this product launch?

You're a product manager at a Surry Hills 'unicorn' startup. The founders want to pivot the product to serve the fossil fuel mining industry in Queensland to keep revenue up. Half your dev team threatens to walk out over climate concerns. Do you push the pivot to save the company or back your team?

A Brisbane-based SaaS company is replacing their local customer support team with an AI trained on the chat logs of the very people they are firing. The CEO calls it 'efficiency,' the workers call it theft of their knowledge. Do you oversee the model training?

You work for a major tech firm in Barangaroo. The 'culture' involves mandatory drinking sessions and 'work hard, play hard' hours that effectively exclude parents and anyone who doesn't fit the 'tech bro' mold. HR asks you to use AI to screen resumes for 'cultural fit,' which will reinforce this bias. Do you comply?

A crypto startup on the Gold Coast is clearly a 'pump and dump' scheme targeting financially illiterate young men. They offer you a huge pile of equity to lend your reputable name as CTO to legitimize the project. Do you take the gig knowing the inevitable crash will hurt thousands of retail investors?

You're a junior dev at a startup in Chippendale. You discover the app is harvesting contact lists from users without proper consent to spam invites, violating Australian privacy laws. Your boss says 'move fast and break things, we'll pay the fine later.' Do you report them to the OAIC?

A large software company wants to buy a small, beloved Wollongong community platform just to shut it down because it competes with their inferior product. You are on the M&A team; do you facilitate this 'kill acquisition'?

You are building a 'Buy Now, Pay Later' algorithm targeting university students in Sydney. The model specifically targets users at 2 AM on weekends when impulse control is low. It drives revenue but creates debt spirals. Do you tweak the algorithm to be less predatory?

A consulting firm in North Sydney asks you to fudge the numbers on a tech impact report to justify outsourcing 500 local IT jobs to a cheaper offshore hub, claiming it improves 'service quality' when you know it doesn't. Do you cook the books?

NSW Police want access to the real-time Opal card transport data to track 'persons of interest' without a warrant. As a database administrator for Transport for NSW, you see a request that looks like they are tracking a political protest organizer, not a criminal. Do you grant access?

You are installing security systems at a major Sydney stadium. The client wants facial recognition at the turnstiles to spot banned fans, but the system also logs the emotional state and attendance habits of every regular punter for marketing purposes. Do you enable the marketing analytics module?

A chain of pubs in Brisbane uses ID scanners (Scantek). They want to sell the patron data (who goes where, at what time) to third-party data brokers. You are the privacy officer; the law is grey, but the ethics are clear. Do you block the sale?

You're developing AI for CCTV cameras in Sydney's CBD. The brief is to detect 'suspicious behavior,' but the training data heavily biases against homeless people and groups of Indigenous youth just hanging out. Do you release the model knowing it will lead to harassment?

A council in Western Sydney wants to install 'smart poles' that listen for gunshots. However, the microphones are sensitive enough to record private conversations on the street. They ask you to lower the privacy masking to improve detection rates. Do you do it?

Workplace surveillance software is being rolled out in a logistics warehouse in Western Sydney. It tracks every second a worker is idle, including bathroom breaks, and automatically issues warnings. You are the system integrator; do you implement the 'time-off-task' penalty feature?

Police ask for footage from your smart doorbell company regarding a robbery. However, they also want a 'dragnet' of all footage from the entire street for the last 48 hours, invading the privacy of dozens of innocent neighbors. Do you hand over the bulk data?

You manage a drone fleet for shark spotting on NSW beaches. The police request your live feed to monitor compliance with a public gathering ban during a protest on the sand. This repurposes safety tech for surveillance. Do you share the feed?

You work for an insurer analyzing flood risk in Lismore. Your new AI model predicts a 99% chance of repeat flooding for a specific street, which would make their premiums unaffordable and their homes worthless. Releasing this data destroys the community's equity overnight. Do you publish the granular map?

After the Northern Rivers floods, a government app is launched to distribute grants. It requires a high-end smartphone and digital ID verification (myGovID), effectively excluding the elderly and poorest victims who lost their devices in the flood. Do you push for a non-digital alternative despite the cost?

A 'Resilient Homes' buyback algorithm prioritizes purchasing homes based on 'economic value' rather than 'human vulnerability.' This means wealthy riverfront owners get bailed out before low-income families in flood basins. Do you adjust the weighting to favor social equity?

You operate a drone mapping service in the Northern Rivers. During a disaster, you capture footage of people in distress. Media outlets offer you huge money for the exclusive rights to the footage of suffering people before rescuers arrive. Do you sell the footage?

A real estate portal asks you to hide the 'flood zone' warning deep in the UI for properties in Brisbane, arguing that it scares off buyers and 'the 2022 flood was a one-off.' You know it wasn't. Do you bury the warning?

You are designing an IoT sensor network for a flood-prone levee. The budget is tight, and the client wants to use cheap, unencrypted sensors. If these get hacked or jammed during a storm, the town won't get the evacuation warning. Do you refuse the contract unless security is improved?

An AI model predicts climate refugees will move to a specific regional town. Developers want this data to buy up land cheap before the migration happens, effectively gentrifying the 'safe' zones. Do you sell the predictive data to the developers?

A grassroots 'Mud Army' volunteer app collected data on thousands of helpers. A political party now wants to buy that database to target voters in the next state election, claiming it's for 'community outreach.' Do you sell the list?

You are training a voice recognition system for a government services hotline. It struggles to understand strong Vietnamese or Lebanese accents common in Western Sydney. Management says 'good enough' and wants to deploy, which will cut off non-native speakers from Centrelink support. Do you halt deployment?

A predictive policing algorithm targets 'gang crime' hotspots. The data is historically biased, focusing heavily on postcodes in Southwest Sydney with high Muslim populations, leading to over-policing of innocent youth. Do you refuse to calibrate the model on this tainted data?

A food delivery app algorithm penalizes riders who take breaks for prayer times, effectively discriminating against observant Muslim riders in Lakemba. The company says it's just 'efficiency optimization.' Do you patch the code to allow for religious observance?

You're building a content moderation bot for a local social platform. It keeps flagging harmless colloquialisms used by Pacific Islander communities as 'aggressive' or 'spam' because the training data is too Anglo-centric. Do you fight for a budget to hire community annotators?

A Smart City project in Haymarket (Chinatown) tracks pedestrian flow using Wi-Fi sniffing. The data creates a perfect map of community gatherings. Federal agencies want this data to monitor for 'foreign interference' without evidence. Do you hand it over?

A loan approval algorithm for a bank automatically downgrades applicants with names that are statistically likely to remit money overseas, hurting first-generation immigrants. You spot the correlation. Do you remove the 'remittance risk' factor?

A health app for diverse communities translates medical advice using generic machine translation. It mistranslates 'positive test result' in a way that causes panic in the Chinese community. Management won't pay for human translators. Do you take the app offline?

You work for a job-matching platform. Employers are unconsciously filtering out candidates with non-Anglo names. You could build a feature that anonymizes names on resumes to force merit-based assessment, but paying clients (recruiters) hate it. Do you build it anyway?
